utterances: Sales from Russia's vast reserves of oil and gas are powering this economy to levels not seen since its dramatic post-communist collapse.
Business success is also changing foreign policy.
Officials have made no secret of their belief Russia's economic recovery entitles it to flex political muscle on the world stage.
Russia has recently forced its former Soviet neighbors to pay much more for gas and cut energy supplies to Ukraine and Belarus over price disputes that disrupted deliveries to Western Europe.
Moscow also recently forced the Shell Oil Company to hand over the largest foreign investment project in Russia to Gazprom.
Western governments say Russia is using energy to bully its rivals, but the Kremlin's actions are popular back home.
(Speaking foreign language).
(Soundbite of laughter)
There's a ton and you can actually go online at the uspto.gov and check it out and see everything that they have opposed in the past.
There is a company, I believe, called ""Mex and the City"" right now that must have slid past their…
Slid past their view.
A Mexican restaurant?
I believe so.
Well, okay.
So, there's not much chance of there being confusion in terms of your business and the TV show.
People are going to - they're going to figure out that yours is a different business altogether.
However, are they arguing, in fact, that you using that name because it sounds so much like their TV show, ""Sex and the City"" that it just, that it dilutes their trademark?
Well, that's going to be up to the USPTO.
The lawyer that I spoke with over at HBO actually did admit that my logo and my Web site, which is healthandthecity.net, looks nothing like their logo.
I'm not trying to use their imagery or either, even colors or anything like that.
So, again, she did admit that it didn't look like that at all.
But you can see their point, though, that you are sort of using their name, in a sense.
So, you're invoking…
I'm not using their name.
I'm just using the phrase, and the city, and is, you know, I can't see how HBO can claim that phrase.
It's very general.
If you had to, what would you rename your business?

So, they actually asked me to change it to ""Health in the City"" and that would cost me thousands of dollars in marketing and changing my Web site, changing my e-mail, changing my brochures and all of that stuff.
So I'm not going to do it.
So you're going to fight them?
I am, I am, and I think I have a good case and people on the blog, on the Wall Street Journal blog that I was written up on, seem to agree with me that I do have a good case.
Have you hired a lawyer?
Well, I'm a very small business woman starting out, single in New York, you know.
Hey, hey, hey, that sounds familiar.
Yeah.
And so, you know, it's tough to get legal help out there.
So hopefully, some nice - where might take me on pro bono, but until then, it's me.
Well, maybe HBO should create a show based around you?
Why not?
Then everyone would be a winner.
I think that's a great idea.
(Soundbite of laughter)
All right.
Jennifer Cassetta, thanks for joining us.
Thank you.
Jennifer Cassetta is fighting a trademark dispute with a television cable company HBO.
In other labor news, New York City is bracing for what might, just perhaps, be a taxi strike tomorrow.
Nobody knows for sure because taxi drivers have no formal union, but a group that claims to represent a majority of the drivers is asking them to stay home for two days.
They're protesting the installation of video screens and GPS monitors in the cabs.
Taxi drivers have had a rocky labor history documented by Colgate University Professor Graham Hodges in his book ""Taxi!
A Social History of the New York City Cabdriver."" He also used to drive a cab in Manhattan himself.
Welcome to the program.
Thanks for asking me back.
Taxi drivers have always complained about fares and all the rules they have to follow.
But what's their beef with these GPS systems?
Well, the New York Taxi Workers Alliance in the past has struck over wages, but this time it's over conditions.
They're unhappy about the installation of the GPS system.
The costs of these systems seems to be fairly high, about $7,000, and that will be borne by the drivers.

There will also be a credit card system available, but the drivers are complaining that the commission system of the card will be five percent, which is substantially higher than that in a restaurant.
It also seems to be very noisy...
Because there's a video screen there.
There's a video screen, but there's also advertising.
It goes on throughout their work hours.
It also beeps apparently and it breaks down very quickly if it's not properly adjusted, and then they have to go back and get it fixed before they can work anymore.
Well, historically cabdrivers are always sort of worried about their freedoms and the rules that restrict their movement, right?
Yes, they have.
One of the reasons that people have gone into cab driving is because they liked to work by themselves.
They like to move around as they see fit.
And this will sharply limit that.
It would be almost like working on a clock.
Well, in your book you talk about how cabdrivers have tried to unionize over the last 100 years; they've had some successes.
Yet they've never managed the fully organize.
Why is that?

Well, cabdrivers did organize in the 1960s with the assistance of Mayor Robert Wagner, and mayors who worked well with cabdrivers seem to have a good system of organization, so there were organized, an AFL-CIO local at that time.
It's now moribund.
And so presently we have the New York Taxi Workers Alliance; that's a union in all but name.
Well, you talked about how taxi drivers are these independent creatures.
Is it just hard for them to organize with their brothers in the other cabs?
Historically, cabdrivers have suffered in something called cabbie-itis, which does indicate a loner quality.
But I must say I'm very impressed by the organizational efforts of the Taxi Workers Alliance.
I think they're doing a good job in trying to bring the drivers together under very difficult circumstances.
Well, everyone's watching to see how many cabbies actually stay home tomorrow and how many yellow cars will be on the street in New York City.
Is this a test of whether these independent workers can stick together?
I think that you'll see most of the New York City Taxi Workers Alliance people staying out.
You'll see a lot of yellow cabs driven by owner-drivers.
Historically, they have not observed strikes.
There will be, of course, some drivers who are not aligned with anybody; they'll also be out there.
Probably as well you'll see a number of livery drivers, more black cabs.
It's hard to say how the city is going to respond to this, but there'll probably be some bending of the rules.
Graham Hodges, author of the book ""Taxi!
A Social History of the New York City Cabdriver."" Thanks for joining us.
It's my pleasure.
Always good to talk to you.
Maybe you've come across the following statistic recently in your reading about the California drought.
It apparently takes one gallon of water to grow a single almond.
And California grows a lot of almonds, along with many of the fruits and vegetables we eat in this country.
So are we making the states drought worse by eating these foods?
We brought in NPR's food and farming correspondent Dan Charles to help us sort it out.
Hey, Dan.
Happy to do your sorting for you.
Thank you.
So let's talk about this.
A gallon of water for a single almond?
I mean, that's crazy.
It seems crazy.
